content.raw:
In vrc task 1, publishing a command to change vehicle direction (`/drc_vehicle/direction/cmd`) produces the error message

```
#!c++

Error [Publisher.cc:84] Publishing an uninitialized message on topic[/gazebo/vrc_task_1/visual]. Required field [id, parent_name] missing.
```

Looks like we need to update [DRCVehiclePlugin.cc](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/drcsim/src/default/plugins/DRCVehiclePlugin.cc) to publish visual msgs with an id and parent_name
content.html:
In vrc task 1, publishing a command to change vehicle direction (/drc_vehicle/direction/cmd) produces the error message

Error [Publisher.cc:84] Publishing an uninitialized message on topic[/gazebo/vrc_task_1/visual]. Required field [id, parent_name] missing.

Looks like we need to update DRCVehiclePlugin.cc to publish visual msgs with an id and parent_name

content.raw:
I guess this is one case in which requiring visual id's for visual messages makes the API less convenient.

@nkoenig Should we provide a helper function `Scene::GetVisualId(std::string)` that will give you the Id of a visual if you provide its name? Then you could call `rendering::get_scene` and then get the visual Id's; would that work?
content.html:
I guess this is one case in which requiring visual id's for visual messages makes the API less convenient.

@nkoenig Should we provide a helper function Scene::GetVisualId(std::string) that will give you the Id of a visual if you provide its name? Then you could call rendering::get_scene and then get the visual Id's; would that work?

content.raw: I'm on it.
content.html: I'm on it.

content.raw: You can call `Scene::GetVisual(std::string)` to get a Visual, the `Visual::GetId()` to get the Visual's ID.
content.html: You can call Scene::GetVisual(std::string) to get a Visual, the Visual::GetId() to get the Visual's ID.

content.raw: I fixed this by making the `id` in proto messages optional. If the `id` is not present, Gazebo will do a normal name lookup.
content.html: I fixed this by making the id in proto messages optional. If the id is not present, Gazebo will do a normal name lookup.

content.html: Jenkins results. Two failures but they pass on my local machine

content.html: Should we target this to default?

content.raw: This looks like an API change. Do we want to give a default value for `_parentId` or deprecate the old function call? There's other changes like this, but I'm only marking this one.
content.html: This looks like an API change. Do we want to give a default value for _parentId or deprecate the old function call? There's other changes like this, but I'm only marking this one.

content.html: Fixed.

content.html: I think we could add the -g, --gui-plugin option for loading gui plugins, since that option should get passed to the client.

content.raw:
Actually I just tried it with the [gui plugin tutorial](http://gazebosim.org/wiki/Tutorials/1.9/plugins/camera_plugin), and `gazebo -g libsystem_gui.so` didn't load properly. So we shouldn't add it to the man-file.
~~~
Warning [parser.cc:356] No <sdf> element in file[~/tutorials/system_gui_plugin/build/libsystem_gui.so]
Error [parser_urdf.cc:2630] Unable to load file[~/tutorials/system_gui_plugin/build/libsystem_gui.so].
Warning [parser.cc:356] No <sdf> element in file[urdf file]
Error [parser.cc:273] parse as old deprecated model file failed.
Error [Server.cc:293] Unable to read sdf file[libsystem_gui.so]
^C^\Quit (core dumped)
~~~

content.raw: It makes sense to give this a unique id, but I noticed that [Collision::FillMsg](#!/osrf/gazebo/src/6e15b005858d52d8531daf8e253b00b5238250b1/gazebo/physics/Collision.cc#cl-301) calls this function, so it might be generating multiple id's over time. I'm not sure how often `Collision::FillMsg` gets called though.
content.html: It makes sense to give this a unique id, but I noticed that Collision::FillMsg calls this function, so it might be generating multiple id's over time. I'm not sure how often Collision::FillMsg gets called though.

content.raw: Thanks, fixed.
content.html: Thanks, fixed.

content.raw: Should this be `++g_uniqueId;`? Since `g_uniqueId` is initialized to 0, it will initially assign a unique id of 0 to the first entity to call this function. However, I noticed in other places (for example [Link.cc:79](#!/osrf/gazebo/pull-request/561/performance-improvements/diff#Lgazebo/physics/Link.ccT79)), that an id of 0 was special and referred to the world.
content.html: Should this be ++g_uniqueId;? Since g_uniqueId is initialized to 0, it will initially assign a unique id of 0 to the first entity to call this function. However, I noticed in other places (for example Link.cc:79), that an id of 0 was special and referred to the world.

content.raw: Done.

There are a lot of places in this pull request, in which we use a for loop and vector iterators for doing something with each vector element. I would consider to use BOOST_FOREACH. For example:

for (Link_V::iterator liter = this->links.begin();
      liter!= this->links.end(); ++liter)
  {
    if (*liter)
    {
      (*liter)->SetGravityMode(_v);
  }

BOOST_FOREACH(LinkPtr link, this->links)
  {
    if (link)
    {
      link->SetGravityMode(_v);
    }  
  }

content.raw: Is BOOST_FOREACH more efficient? My experience with boost is that performance is sacrificed for convenience.
content.html: Is BOOST_FOREACH more efficient? My experience with boost is that performance is sacrificed for convenience.

content.raw:
After a little googling, I believe BOOST_FOREACH is ineffcient (compared to hand coded).

In c++11 there is also a new ranged for which is even better:
http://www.open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2009/n2930.html

Ranged for is supported in gcc 4.6 and above. I'm not sure about osx.
content.html:
After a little googling, I believe BOOST_FOREACH is ineffcient (compared to hand coded).

In c++11 there is also a new ranged for which is even better: http://www.open-std.org/JTC1/SC22/WG21/docs/papers/2009/n2930.html

Ranged for is supported in gcc 4.6 and above. I'm not sure about osx.

content.raw: That's a good point to keep the loops as they are.
content.html: That's a good point to keep the loops as they are.

content.raw:
My blackbox manual tests did not show any error or unexpected behaviour. Running gazebo alone with PR2 and visualize sensors is just fine. Build drcsim on top of this version and running a trial scenario with atlas and visualize data in RVIZ was just fine also.

I launched some jobs in jenkins:

 * [Standard any + graphic stuff on quantal](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64-gpu-nvidia/40/).
 * [Standard any + drcsim default on quantal](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/drcsim-any-gazebo-any-devel-quantal-amd64/). It is in the waiting queue. 
 * [Performance analysis](http://build.osrfoundation.org/job/gazebo-perf_nate-performance-quantal-amd64/): it is in the queue the run that will build default branch. And after it, we should launch the one with pref_nate as parameter. Performance analysis should come automatically.

I must go now, so if the jenkins analysis ends up ok, you have my approval.
content.html:
My blackbox manual tests did not show any error or unexpected behaviour. Running gazebo alone with PR2 and visualize sensors is just fine. Build drcsim on top of this version and running a trial scenario with atlas and visualize data in RVIZ was just fine also.

I launched some jobs in jenkins:

  • Standard any + graphic stuff on quantal.
  • Standard any + drcsim default on quantal. It is in the waiting queue.
  • Performance analysis: it is in the queue the run that will build default branch. And after it, we should launch the one with pref_nate as parameter. Performance analysis should come automatically.

I must go now, so if the jenkins analysis ends up ok, you have my approval.
